title: Minneapolis Fed Chief Now Sees Sees Two 2022 Rate Rises; More Signs of Tight U.S. Labor Market
text:
Top News

Fed's Neel Kashkari Now Sees Two Rate Rises This Year

Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis President Neel Kashkari, who has been one of the central bank's biggest supporters of providing stimulus to help the economy navigate the coronavirus pandemic, said he now believes more aggressive monetary policy actions will be needed to deal with high inflation.

In an essay posted on the bank's website, Mr. Kashkari also said he supported the Fed decision last month to accelerate the drawdown of its asset-buying stimulus effort.

Companies See Funding Staying Cheap, Despite Looming Rate Rises

Many U.S. finance chiefs secured cheap funding for their businesses in 2021 and anticipate similar conditions in 2022, although expected rate increases by the Federal Reserve are prompting companies to refinance some debt coming due over the next few years.

Derby's Take: Aggressive Rate Increase Path Could Threaten Fed Profits, Report Warns

By Michael S. Derby

A top economist at J.P. Morgan says keeping the Federal Reserve's books in the black could motivate the central bank to start an earlier and faster runoff of its balance sheet.

Michael Feroli in a note to J.P. Morgan clients on Tuesday wrote that the status of Fed profits is politically fraught, because of the money the central bank makes for the federal government. As a self-funded government agency, the Fed collects interest on bonds it owns—it buys securities with money it creates out of thin air—and charges fees for services for banks. And after the Fed covers its expenses, it turns over the excess to the Treasury Department. Read more.

U.S. Economy

Workers Quit Jobs at a Record Level in November

The Labor Department said the total number of quits reached 4.5 million after slightly falling in October from the previous month. The quits rate was 3%, up from 2.8% the prior month and returning to a record rate last seen in September.

Build Back Better Takes Back Seat to Democrats' Election-Law Push

Senate Democrats put the party's marquee economic package on ice, shifting their attention to passing elections legislation as they consider how to overhaul the roughly $2 trillion education, healthcare and climate bill.

U.S. Prevails Over Canada in Dairy Dispute

The U.S. prevailed in a dispute over policies in Canada aimed at shielding its dairy industry from competition, according to a ruling published from the first dispute resolution panel under the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement.

Markets Jingle, but Not All the Way, to a Santa Rally

Santa Claus came to Wall Street again. U.S. indexes mostly rose to start 2022 in a so-called Santa Claus rally, reflecting that many investors are still enthusiastic for stocks even in a market that has recently notched multiple record highs.

Key Developments Around the World

Oil Jumps as OPEC Sees Limited Omicron Impact

OPEC and a Russia-led group of oil producers agreed to continue pumping more crude, pushing oil prices higher as they bet the Omicron variant of Covid-19 won't hit demand as previous waves of the virus.

Lockdown of Chinese City Leaves 13 Million Stranded

A week and a half into one of China's biggest pandemic lockdowns, Xi'an residents voiced desperation online about challenges in getting food and medical care as Covid-19-control seems to trump all other priorities in the city.

Europe Struggles to Meet China's Trade Challenge

China's economic pushback against the European Union over Lithuania's outreach to Taiwan has sparked divisions in the EU and raised fresh doubts about its ability to shield its giant market from Beijing's pressure.

Forward Guidance

Thursday (all times ET)

8:30 a.m.: U.S. Commerce Department releases November international trade data

9 a.m.: European Central Bank's Schnabel gives speech

1:15 p.m.: St. Louis Fed's Bullard speaks on economy and monetary policy to CFA Society St. Louis

Friday

8:30 a.m.: U.S. Labor Department releases December jobs report

10 a.m.: San Francisco Fed's Daly speaks at American Economic Association virtual conference

12:15 p.m.: Atlanta Fed's Bostic speaks at American Economic Association virtual conference

12:30 p.m.: Richmond Fed's Barkin speaks to Maryland Bankers Association in Baltimore

3 p.m.: Federal Reserve releases November consumer credit

Research

Goldman Sachs Sees Inflation Pressures Ebbing Later This Year

There is some light at the end of the tunnel for the current inflation surge in the U.S., according to Goldman Sachs economists. They wrote in a note to clients Tuesday that compared with the 4.7% year-over-year increase in the core personal-consumption expenditures price index in November, core inflation should ease to 2.5% by year-end and to 2.15% by the close of 2023. "We expect that ongoing supply chain disruptions will raise the prices of some goods further above the pre-pandemic trend and boost core inflation through early 2022," the economists wrote, adding that "declines in durable goods prices are likely to drive inflation lower by end-2022, more than offsetting a sharp acceleration in shelter inflation."

—Michael S. Derby

Commentary

How to Brace for the Year of Central Bank Divergence

With inflation-adjusted yields low, expanding profit margins and the dollar steered by short-term yield differentials, the Fed's divorce from the ECB and the BOJ could—counterintuitively—create some extra love for America's currency and its assets, Jon Sindreu writes.

Factories Took a Small Step Back Toward Normal

American manufacturers ran a wee bit less hot last month. The Institute for Supply Management said its index of manufacturing activity slipped to 58.7 in December from 61.1 in November. How that happened is what matters, writes Justin Lahart.

Basis Points

Brazil's central bank will raise the Selic at its first three policy meetings this year, lifting the benchmark lending rate to 12.25% from the current level of 9.25% by May, according to economists at Banco MUFG Brasil SA. (Dow Jones Newswires)

Canadian producer prices advanced in November as higher costs for chemicals largely powered a 0.8% rise in the country's industrial product price index from the previous month, Statistics Canada said. In October, producer prices climbed by a revised 1.6%. On a 12-month basis, the index advanced 18.1%. (DJN)

China's central bank will likely replenish liquidity shortfalls ahead of the Lunar New Year holiday, state-owned China Securities Journal said. The People's Bank of China normally maintains ample liquidity at the start of the year, the newspaper said. However, liquidity in January this year will be affected by various factors, especially the Lunar New Year holiday that falls earlier in February, it reported.

The Monetary Authority of Singapore may tighten policy more aggressively at its semiannual review in April, owing to Singapore's price pressures broadening and upside risks rising since the October review, TD Securities says. The MAS is likely to recenter the midpoint of its SGD nominal effective exchange rate policy band upward and raise the band's slope by 50 bps, the brokerage predicts. (DJN)

Germany's unemployment rate fell to 5.2% in December from 5.3% in November, putting the rate at just 0.2 percentage points above its pre-virus level in February 2020, driven by a solid 522,000 fall in jobless claims since June 2020. (DJN)

The Polish zloty stayed higher versus the euro after the country's central bank raised its key interest rate by a further 50 basis points to 2.25% to rein in inflation. The decision was widely expected and comes after the central bank slowed its monetary policy tightening to a 50bp rate rise in December from a 75bp increase in November, Capital Economics economist Liam Peach says. (DJN)

Factory activity in the U.K. continued to expand solidly in December, with output increasing on a rise in intakes of new work, according to a survey of purchasing managers from IHS Markit. Its manufacturing PMI came in at 57.9 in December, marginally down from 58.1 in November and indicative of a robust growth rate. (DJN)
